What are the functional roles of noradre: Noradrenergic neurons play a crucial role in regulating arousal, autonomic function, and cognitive processes such as attention and memory. They also play a role in skeletal muscle contraction and relaxation.
What are th effects of noradrenaline rel: Noradrenaline release in the CNS can have a variety of effects, including enhancing focus and attention, promoting learning and memory, and regulating bodily functions such as heart rate and blood pressure. It also plays a role in stress response and anxiety.
How many amino acids make up the D1 rece: The D1 receptor is made up of 446 amino acids.
What do the D2 receptors often act as ?: D2 receptors often act as autoreceptors, regulating dopamine neuron activity and controlling the synthesis, release, and uptake of dopamine.
What can excessive dopamine cause ?: Excessive dopamine can cause a variety of symptoms, including insomnia, anxiety, and depression. It can also be linked to mental health disorders such as schizophrenia, ADHD, and addiction.
What is current ?: Current is the rate at which electric charge flows past a point in a complete electrical circuit, typically measured in amperes (amps). It represents the movement of charge carriers, such as electrons, through a conductor over time. In essence, current quantifies how much electric charge is moving through a circuit at any given moment.
If you get an inward positive current wh: If you get an inward positive current, the postsynaptic potential becomes more positive, or depolarized. For example, the potential may move from -65 to -63 mV for example. This depolarization increases the probability that an action potential will be produced in the postsynaptic cell.
What is another name for ionotropic acet: Another name for ionotropic acetylcholine receptors is nicotinic receptors.
What is the general structure and functi: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are multi-subunit transmembrane neurotransmitter receptors with a basic structure consisting of a large extracellular domain, four transmembrane domains, and a cytoplasmic domain. They function as ligand-gated ion channels, mediating the fast synaptic actions of acetylcholine in both the central and peripheral nervous systems, as well as in non-neuronal cells.
Which domain of each subunit in nicotini: The transmembrane segment 2 (TM2) -helix of each subunit in the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor faces into the channel.
What happens to nAChR when the concentra: When the concentration of acetylcholine increases, nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) first become activated, leading to ion channel opening and subsequent cellular responses. However, prolonged exposure to high concentrations of acetylcholine can cause desensitization of the receptors, reducing their responsiveness to further stimulation.
What are the subunits for nAChR in muscl: The nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) in muscle is composed of four subunits with the stoichiometry 2.
What subunits for nAChR are present in t: The most abundant nAChR subunits in the brain are 7 homopentamers and 42 heteropentamers.
What effect does changing the subunits o: Changing the subunits of an ionotropic receptor can have a significant impact on its function and signaling pathways. This can include changes in single-channel conductances, rates of desensitization, and sensitivity to activators and inactivators.
What are the ionotropic receptors for gl: The ionotropic receptors for glutamate are AMPA, NMDA, and kainate receptors.
What are AMPA receptors important for ?: AMPA receptors are important for mediating glutamatergic synaptic transmission and plasticity, which play a major role in memory and learning processes.
What are kainate receptors important for: Kainate receptors are important for mediating the actions of glutamate, both pre- and postsynaptically. They play a role in synaptic plasticity, transmission of neuropathic pain, and modulation of neuronal excitability.
How many subunits for glutamatergic rece: Glutamatergic receptors typically have four subunits: NMDA receptors have GluN1, 2A-D, 3A-B, and AMPA receptors have GluA1-4.
What are the types of AMPA receptors ?: AMPA receptors are tetrameric ion channels composed of four subunits: GluA1, GluA2, GluA3, and GluA4. These subunits can combine in various ways to form different types of AMPA receptors, including GluR1/A, GluR2/B, GluR3/C, and GluR4/D, respectively.
What is the structure of an NMDA recepto: The structure of an NMDA receptor resembles a mushroom, with a height of approximately 150  and widths of approximately 125  120. It is composed of five subunits, each with a similar amino acid sequence to other glutamate receptors.
What can ions flow through NMDA receptor: Ions that can flow through NMDA receptors include sodium (Na+), calcium (Ca2+), and potassium (K+).
What is an example of an antagonist for: An example of an antagonist for AMPA/kainate receptors is 2,3-dihydroxy-6-nitro-7-sulphamoyl-benzo[f]quinoxaline (NBQX).
An example of an antagonist for NMDA receptors is memantine.
What are GABAa receptors like ?: GABAa receptors are heteropentamers composed of various subunits, including six alpha, three beta, and three gamma subunits. They form a chloride-ion-permeable channel with GABA binding sites located at the junction of +/ subunits.
Which acetylcholine receptors are more p: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are more prominent in the brain.
What are the metabotropic acetylcholine: Metabotropic acetylcholine receptors (mAChRs), also known as muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (mAChRs), are G protein-coupled receptors characterized by seven helical membrane-spanning domains. Unlike nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which are ligand-gated ion channels, mAChRs activate intracellular signaling pathways through G proteins.
What are the metabotropic glutamate rece: Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) are a family of G-protein-coupled receptors that bind to glutamate and transmit signals through intracellular signaling pathways. There are eight subtypes of mGluRs, each with unique molecular and pharmacological properties.
what did the organs of balance originate: The organs of balance originated from the inner ear, specifically the vestibular system.
what is the function of the vestibular s: The vestibular system functions to maintain balance, body orientation, and coordination of head and eye movements. It senses head movements and sends signals to the brain to control posture and eye movements.
what are the 2 main structures of the ve: The two main structures of the vestibular labyrinth are the otolith organs (the saccule and utricle) and the three semicircular canals (anterior, posterior, and lateral).
what do the otolith organs detect?: The otolith organs detect linear acceleration, gravitational forces, and tilting movements. Specifically, the utricle is responsible for detecting horizontal acceleration, while the saccule senses vertical acceleration. This information is passed on to the brain through sensory hair cells.
what do the semicircular canals?: The semicircular canals are three tiny tubes in the inner ear that regulate balance and sense head position. They contain fluid that moves as you turn your head, providing information about rotational movements and body orientation. Each canal is oriented at right angles to the others, allowing for the detection of different types of head movements.
what makes up the otolith organs ?: The otolith organs are made up of two structures: the utricle and sacculus. The utricle is the smaller of the two, and it contains sensory cells called maculae that detect head position. The sacculus is the larger of the two, and it contains a gelatinous layer and an otolithic membrane embedded with calcium carbonate crystals called otoconia.
what makes up the semicircular canals?: The semicircular canals are three looped tubes in the inner ear, each filled with a fluid called endolymph and lined with a hair-like sensor called the cupula. They are part of the bony labyrinth and help detect head movements and balance.
what is the macula ?: The macula is a small, highly pigmented area near the center of the retina. It is responsible for central vision and detailed tasks such as reading and recognizing faces. It contains a high concentration of cone cells, particularly in the fovea, which allows for precise and detailed vision.
what the process that occurs when the he: When the head angle changes or accelerates, a force is exerted on the otoliths in the inner ear. This force causes the gelatinous cap of the otoliths to deform, which in turn stimulates the movement of hair cells at the organ of corti. This stimulates the transmission of electrical signals to the brain, allowing for balance and coordination.
what happens to the otolith organs on ea: The otolith organs on each side of the head are responsible for detecting linear acceleration and gravity. The utricle senses horizontal movements, while the saccule senses vertical movements. The otolith organs work by using a gelatinous membrane with embedded calcium carbonate crystals that shift in response to head movements, bending the hair cells to send signals to the brain.
what acceleration is detected by the oto: The otolith organs detect linear acceleration, while the semicircular canals detect angular acceleration.
where are the hair cells in the semicirc: The hair cells in the semicircular canals are located at the base of the ampulla.
when do the cilia bend in the semicircul: The cilia in the semicircular canals bend when the head changes position, as the endolymph fluid in the ducts lags behind due to inertia and acts on the cupula. This bending stimulates the hair cells, which then send signals to the brain about angular acceleration.
what is the acitvity like in the vestibu: At rest, the vestibular axons exhibit a low level of activity. However, they are still able to detect changes in head position and motion, and transmit this information to the brain.
what is the central vestibular pathway ?: The central vestibular pathway is responsible for processing information from the vestibular system in the inner ear to elicit motor responses for balance and orientation. It involves the transmission of information from the vestibular end organs via the vestibular branch of the eighth cranial nerve to the brainstem and cerebellum. This pathway integrates peripheral signals to elicit motor responses that stabilize posture and gaze.
What extra molecule does glutamate have: Glutamate has an extra methylene group compared to aspartate.
What are the 2 excitatory neurotransmitt: The two excitatory neurotransmitters in the brain are glutamate and acetylcholine.
Are glutamate and aspartate essential or: Both glutamate and aspartate are non-essential amino acids, meaning they can be synthesized by the body and do not need to be obtained through diet.
What is the abundance of glutamate and a: Glutamine is the most abundant amino acid in the brain, with concentrations ranging from 5-15 mmol per kg of brain tissue. Aspartate is also present, but its abundance is less than glutamate.
What is pathway 1 for the synthesis of g: Pathway 1 for the synthesis of glutamate involves the conversion of glutamine to glutamate with the help of the enzyme glutaminase.
What is pathway 2 in the synthesis of gl: Pathway 2 in the synthesis of glutamate is called glutaminolysis, where glutamine is catabolized by glutaminase to form glutamate. This glutamate can then be converted to -ketoglutarate by glutamate dehydrogenases (GDHs) or transaminases (GOTs).
What is the glutamine cycle ?: The glutamine cycle, also known as the glutamate-glutamine cycle, is a metabolic pathway that involves the transfer of carbon and nitrogen units between neurons and astrocytes. Neurons release glutamate, which is taken up by astrocytes and converted into glutamine. Glutamine is then released by astrocytes, transported back into neurons, and converted back into glutamate, completing the cycle.
What 3 types of cells are present in the: The three types of cells present in the glutamine cycle are neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes.
What happens to glutamate after its rele: After its release, glutamate is primarily taken up by astrocytes, where it is converted to glutamine via glutamine synthetase. This process is part of the glutamate/GABA-glutamine cycle, which helps regulate neurotransmitter levels in the brain.
How is glutamate broken down ?: Glutamate is broken down through a process called oxidative deamination, where it is converted to alpha-ketoglutarate and ammonium ion. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase.
How is glutamate stored into vesicles ?: Glutamate is stored into vesicles by vesicular glutamate transporters (VGLUTs). These transporters concentrate glutamate into synaptic vesicles, driven by membrane potential.
How is glutamate released from the nerve: Glutamate is released from the nerve terminal through a process called exocytosis, where synaptic vesicles containing glutamate fuse with the plasma membrane and release their contents into the synaptic cleft.
What is the transporter for glutamate li: The transporter for glutamate in the presynaptic membrane and glial cell is GLT-1.
Facts about glutamate transporter subtyp: There are five glutamate transporter subtypes: EAAT1, EAAT2, EAAT3, EAAT4, and EAAT5. EAAT1 and EAAT2 are primarily astrocytic, while EAAT1 and EAAT4 are neuronal. EAAT1 and EAAT4 are involved in synaptic transmission, while EAAT1 and EAAT4 are involved in excitatory neurotransmission.
Where are each of the glutamate transpor: The excitatory glutamate transporters (EAATs) are found in the plasma membrane of neurons and astrocytes, while the vesicular glutamate transporters (VGLUTs) are found in the membrane of glutamate-containing synaptic vesicles. The cystine-glutamate antiporter (xCT) is also found in the plasma membrane of cells.
What are the receptors of glutamate like: Glutamate receptors are multi-subunit ion channels that are ligand-gated. They are found in the central nervous system and are responsible for excitatory postsynaptic responses. There are several types of glutamate receptors, including AMPA, NMDA, and kainate receptors.
What are the class 1 metabotropic recept: Class 1 metabotropic receptors, also known as group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluR1 and mGluR5), are a family of G-protein-coupled receptors that mediate the effects of various neurotransmitters and neuromodulators in the central nervous system. They are involved in the regulation of synaptic transmission and neuronal excitability.
What are the class 2 metabotropic glutam: The class 2 metabotropic glutamate receptor, also known as mGluR2, is a G protein-coupled receptor that functions as an autoreceptor for glutamate. Upon activation, it inhibits the release of glutamate at the presynaptic terminal of glutamatergic neurons.
What are the class 3 metabotropic glutam: Class 3 metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) include mGluR7, mGluR8, and mGluR9. They have an inhibitory effect on neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission.
What activates class 1 and 2 metabotropi: Class 1 and 2 metabotropic glutamate receptors are activated by the excitatory neurotransmitter L-glutamate.
What activates class 3 metabotropic glut: Class 3 metabotropic glutamate receptors are activated by the neurotransmitter L-glutamate.
What are agonists, antagonists, channel: Agonists of NMDA receptors include L-glutamate and glycine, while antagonists inhibit the receptor by occluding the ion channel. Channel blockers are compounds that block the ion channel, while modulators are substances that influence the receptor's activity without directly activating it. Co-agonists of NMDA receptors include glycine and L-glutamate.
What are agonists and antagonists of AMP: Agonists of AMPA receptors include glutamate and kainate, while antagonists include -amino acid derivatives and channel blockers.
What effect does polyamine have on NMDA: Polyamines have a biphasic effect on NMDA receptors, either blocking them at high doses or activating them at low concentrations.
What happens when glycine and NMDA bind: When glycine and NMDA (or glutamate) bind to NMDA receptors, they act as coagonists. This results in the opening of an ion conductive pore across the membrane, allowing for signaling between neurons.
What happens when glutamate and glycine: When glutamate and glycine bind to NMDA receptors, they activate the receptors, leading to an increase in calcium permeability. This increase in permeability allows for an increase in calcium influx, which can lead to excitotoxicity in neurons.
Explain long term potentiation: Long-term potentiation (LTP) is a process that strengthens synaptic connections between neurons, enabling learning and memory formation. It occurs when neurons are repeatedly stimulated, enhancing signal transmission efficiency. LTP is considered a key mechanism for learning and memory formation in the brain.
What is long term potentiation involved: Long-term potentiation (LTP) is a process that enhances synaptic transmission and is involved in learning and memory. It is a mechanism that strengthens the connections between neurons when they are repeatedly stimulated. LTP is particularly important in the hippocampus, a brain region that plays a crucial role in memory formation and retrieval.
How does LTP cause synaptic plasticity ?: Long-term potentiation (LTP) causes synaptic plasticity by enhancing the strength of synaptic transmission through a process that involves both pre- and postsynaptic changes. This process involves a cascade of events that involves both pre- and postsynaptic mechanisms, including changes in neurotransmitter release and structural modifications to the postsynaptic membrane.
What happens in neurotoxic cell death ?: Neurotoxic cell death occurs when a neurotoxin damages the nervous system by inhibiting mitochondrial activity, increasing oxidative stress, and up-regulating cell death-related proteins. This can lead to permanent or reversible damage to the nervous system.
What is epilepsy.?: Epilepsy is a neurological condition characterized by recurring, unprovoked seizures. It is caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
What is riluzole used in and why ?: Riluzole is used to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, to slow down the progression of the disease. While it does not improve symptoms, it may extend survival by about 2 to 3 months and delay the need for a breathing tube.
What happen to glutamatergic system in i: In ischemia, the glutamatergic system is disrupted, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium levels and an excessive release of glutamate. This leads to excitotoxicity and neuronal injury.
what drugs can be used to increase the l: Drugs that can be used to increase the levels of serotonin in the synaptic cleft include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which work by blocking the reuptake of serotonin by the serotonin transporter (SERT), thereby boosting serotonin levels and increasing activation of postsynaptic serotonin receptors.
when does serotonin suppress appetite?: Serotonin suppresses appetite primarily in the hypothalamus, where it is involved in regulating satiation and post-meal satiety.
what serotonin receptors are thought to: The serotonin receptors that are thought to be involved in appetite regulation are the 5-HT1B and 5-HT2C receptors.

what is the link between serotonin and d: Serotonin, also known as 'the happy molecule', is a neurotransmitter that plays a role in mood regulation. explain merkel\u2019s disks?: Merkel's disks, also known as tactile discs, are specialized mechanoreceptors located in the skin that detect light touch and texture. They are found in the basal layer of the epidermis and are closely associated with sensory nerve endings, playing a key role in tactile perception, especially in sensitive areas like fingertips and lips. These receptors are slowly adapting and respond to gentle contact, providing important information to the brain about touch.
explain ruffini\u2019s endings?: Ruffini's endings are specialized sensory receptors located in the skin and connective tissues that respond to sustained pressure and skin stretch. They play a key role in proprioception, helping the body perceive its position and movement in space. These receptors are slowly adapting and contribute to the sensation of deep pressure.
explain meissner\u2019s corpuscles?: Meissner's corpuscles are specialized sensory receptors found in the dermal papillae of the skin, particularly in areas like the fingertips and palms. They are sensitive to light touch and low-frequency vibrations, playing a key role in our tactile perception. These mechanoreceptors transmit sensory information to the central nervous system through rapidly adapting, myelinated afferent fibers.
explain pacinian\u2019s corpuscles?: Pacinian corpuscles are specialized sensory receptors located in the skin that detect deep pressure and vibrations. They are characterized by their onion-shaped structure, consisting of concentric layers of connective tissue that amplify mechanical signals to the nerve endings. These receptors are rapidly adapting, meaning they respond to changes in pressure but not to sustained pressure.
what are phased neurons ?: Phased neurons, also known as stochastic phase-change neurons, are artificial neurons based on phase-change materials. They are used for detecting temporal correlations in data streams and in representing high-bandwidth signals. These neurons have dynamics that allow them to enhance computational capabilities in neural networks.
what are tonic neurons?: Tonic neurons are neurons that exhibit low-frequency firing, which typically occurs without presynaptic input and can be viewed as background activity. They are often associated with the persistent activation of certain receptor types, such as GABA A receptors, leading to a tonic current. This contrasts with phasic neurons, which exhibit faster, burst-like firing patterns.
what are accommodating neurons ?: Accommodating neurons are neurons that exhibit a longer interspike interval (ISI) compared to non-accommodating neurons. This is because accommodating neurons are able to adapt to sustained depolarization, whereas non-accommodating neurons are not able to adapt to sustained depolarization.
what are spontaneous active bursting neu: Spontaneous active bursting neurons are a type of neuron that exhibits bursts of rapid spiking followed by periods of quiescence. These bursts can be triggered by a variety of stimuli, including external stimuli such as light or sound, as well as internal stimuli such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and neurotransmitters.
what is the affective aggression pathway: The affective aggression pathway of serotonin involves its projections to the hypothalamus, where it is involved in regulating mood and behavior. what does the utricle detect ?: The utricle detects linear accelerations, particularly horizontal linear accelerations and changes in head position relative to gravity. It also helps maintain balance and postural stability by providing feedback on head position and movement.
what happens when the otolithic membrane: When the otolithic membrane moves, it bends the stereocilia of the hair cells beneath it. This causes the hair cells to send signals to the brain indicating the linear acceleration or tilt of the head.
what happens to movements when the activ: When the activity in the direct pathway in the basal ganglia is increased, it disinhibits motor neurons, allowing them to release motor commands. This allows for more efficient and coordinated movement.
what happens to movements when the indir: When the indirect pathway is activated in the basal ganglia, it helps to suppress unwanted movements and prevent muscle contractions that compete with voluntary movements. what happens when dopamine is released i: When dopamine is released in the striatum, it binds to dopamine receptors and regulates the plasticity of glutamatergic synapses. This process can promote long-term potentiation of recently active glutamatergic input, particularly when accompanied by an unexpected reward. This process is crucial for integrating reward signals and generating appropriate behavioral responses.
what happens when the VA/VL nuclei of th: When the VA/VL nuclei of the thalamus are activated, they project to the primary motor and premotor cortices, where they play a role in motor control.
what are thee 5 cell types in the cerebe: The five cell types in the cerebellar cortex are Purkinje cells, granule cells, basket cells, stellate cells, and Golgi cells.
what cells of the cerebellar cortex actu: The only cells of the cerebellar cortex that actually leave the cerebellum are Purkinje cells (P-cells). These cells have axons that terminate in the cerebellar nuclei and the vestibular nuclei.
what cells of the cerebellar cortex are: The excitatory cells of the cerebellar cortex are granule cells. They receive input from mossy fibers and excite Purkinje cells, which are the sole output synapses of the cerebellar cortex.
what cells of the cerebellar cortex dont: The cells of the cerebellar cortex that do not interact with Purkinje cells are the granule cells. Granule cells are located in the innermost granular layer and do not have direct synaptic interactions with Purkinje cells. Instead, they receive inhibitory input from Golgi cells and send their axons as parallel fibers to the molecular layer.
what are the parallel fibres ?: Parallel fibers are the axons of granule cells located in the cerebellar granule layer that innervate the distal dendritic tree of Purkinje cells. They synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells and run parallel to the cerebellar fissures within the molecular layer. These fibers play a crucial role in the cerebellum's function by integrating inputs and contributing to the generation of simple spike action potentials in Purkinje cells.
explain the pyramidal tract/corticospina: The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is a collection of axons that carry movement-related information from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. It is the major neuronal pathway enabling voluntary motor function, particularly for the movement of distal extremities. The tract starts in the motor cortex and descends through the brainstem, with a majority of its fibers crossing to the contralateral side within the medulla before continuing down the spinal cord.
What is the basal ganglia and frontal co: The basal ganglia acts as a gatekeeper for motor movements, choosing which actions to execute based on inputs from various cortices, including the frontal cortex. The frontal cortex provides information about potential goals and context to the striatum, a major component of the basal ganglia. Together, they play a critical role in deciding what to do and when to move.
What is the pathway for functional hiera: The functional hierarchy of motor systems consists of three levels: reflexes, postural adjustments, and voluntary movements. Reflexes are controlled by the spinal cord and brainstem, while postural adjustments and voluntary movements are controlled by the cerebellum and basal ganglia.
What is the function of the cerebellum a: The cerebellum integrates sensory and motor signals, coordinating and fine-tuning movements. The primary motor area generates neural impulses that pass down to the spinal cord and control movement execution. Together, the cerebellum and primary motor area play a crucial role in the hierarchy of motor output.
What is the function of the primary moto: The primary motor cortex is responsible for generating neural impulses that pass down to the spinal cord to control muscle activity. It encodes information about the force and direction of movement, and coordinates the activity of other motor areas in the hierarchy of action.
What is the direct pathway from the moto: The direct pathway from the motor cortex to the spinal cord is the lateral corticospinal tract. This tract originates in the motor cortex and terminates in the lateral portions of the ventral horn and intermediate gray matter of the spinal cord. It is responsible for voluntary movements of the limbs and trunk.
What is the indirect pathway from the pr: The indirect pathway from the primary motor cortex to spinal cortex involves the corticospinal tract, which runs from the primary motor cortex to the spinal cord.
What is the purpose of the descending up: The purpose of the descending upper motor neurons from basal ganglia to motor cortex is to provide input for the planning and initiation of voluntary movements.

The purpose of the descending upper motor neurons projection to the brainstem centres is to regulate muscle tone and coordinate movements based on sensory information from various modalities, such as vestibular, somatic, auditory, and visual inputs. This regulation is essential for basic navigational movements and maintaining posture.
What are the main functions of brain in: The main functions of the brain in motor control include planning, coordinating, and executing voluntary movements. The primary motor cortex is responsible for initiating and coordinating movements, while other areas of the brain, such as the motor cortex, are involved in modulating and refining movements.
What are the main functions of the spina: The main functions of the spinal cord in motor movements are to transmit motor commands from the brain to the muscles, coordinate reflexes, and integrate sensory information from sensory receptors.
How are the motor systems organised ?: The motor systems are organized in the brain and spinal cord in a hierarchical manner. In the brain, the motor cortex is the primary control center for movement, while the spinal cord is the secondary control center. The motor cortex is responsible for generating and executing motor commands, while the spinal cord is the primary motor control center for voluntary movements.
What areas do the Premotor areas directl: The premotor areas directly control lower motor neurons in the spinal cord through the corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts.
What are the 3 cortical pathways ?: The three cortical pathways are the corticospinal tracts, corticobulbar tracts, and corticostriatal pathways.
What are the 4 BRAINSTEM motor pathways: The four brainstem motor pathways are the reticulospinal tract, rubrospinal tract, tectospinal tract, and vestibulospinal tract.
What pathway only terminates on motor ne: The pathway that only terminates on motor neurons in humans and primates is the corticospinal tract (CST).
What is a motor unit ?: A motor unit is a single motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it stimulates. When the motor neuron fires, all the muscle fibers in that unit contract simultaneously. The size of a motor unit varies and dictates its function, with smaller units allowing finer motor control.
How do motor units vary ?: Motor units vary in size, shape, and number of muscle fibers. Smaller motor units control smaller muscles, while larger motor units control larger muscles. The size and shape of motor units are also influenced by the size and shape of the muscle fibers. The number of muscle fibers within a motor unit also varies, with larger motor units controlling larger muscles and smaller motor units controlling smaller muscles. This variation allows for a range of motion and force production within a single muscle.
Where motor neurons which innervate axia: Motor neurons that innervate axial musculature are located medially, while those that innervate distal musculature are located laterally.
In motor control why do we have a feedba: In motor control, we have a feedback system to detect and correct errors in movement, allowing for more precise and efficient movement. The primary motor cortex is involved in this process, as it integrates sensory information from the environment and motor commands from the spinal cord.
What do alpha motor neurons innervate ?: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are responsible for skeletal muscle contraction.
What is a motor neuron pool ?: A motor neuron pool is a group of motor neurons that innervate a single muscle, with each neuron controlling a specific subset of muscle fibers.
What are the 3 inputs to lower motor neu: The three inputs to lower motor neurons are: 1. Upper motor neurons 2. Sensory inputs 3. Local circuit inputs
Describe fast motor units: Fast motor units, also known as fast fatigable (FF) motor units, are designed for brief, high-force activities like running or jumping. They are characterized by their ability to generate large forces quickly but fatigue rapidly. These units are composed of fast-twitch muscle fibers, which are better suited for explosive, high-intensity movements.
Describe slow motor units: Slow motor units are characterized by a lower innervation ratio, meaning fewer muscle fibers are innervated by a single motor neuron. They are typically found in muscles that require sustained, low-intensity movements, such as the soleus muscle. These units are designed for precise, sustained contractions and are more resistant to fatigue compared to fast motor units.
What are muscle spindles ?: Muscle spindles are encapsulated mechanoreceptors that detect changes in muscle length and velocity. They play a crucial role in proprioception by conveying this information to the central nervous system. Muscle spindles are unique among mechanoreceptors as they possess their own motor innervation, allowing them to be tuned by spinal motor neurons.
Where do group 1a axons project into and: Group 1a axons project into the spinal cord and synapse with alpha motor neurons.
How is an action potential generated in: An action potential in group 1a axons is generated when voltage-gated sodium channels open, allowing a rapid influx of sodium ions into the membrane. This causes depolarization of the membrane and a brief reversal of the membrane potential from -70mV to +30mV. The action potential then propagates along the axon due to changes in ion permeability.
What are extrafusal muscle fibres ?: Extrafusal muscle fibers are ordinary muscle fibers, distinguished from the intrafusal fibers found in muscle spindles. They are long, cylindrical, multinucleated cells that receive motor innervation and are responsible for generating force for movement. Each extrafusal muscle fiber is embedded in a delicate connective tissue layer called the endomysium.
What are intrafusal muscle fibres ?: Intrafusal muscle fibers are specialized skeletal muscle fibers that function as proprioceptors, detecting changes in muscle length and the rate of that change. They are found within muscle spindles and are innervated by both sensory and motor fibers, playing a crucial role in the muscle stretch reflex. Unlike extrafusal fibers, which are responsible for muscle contraction, intrafusal fibers primarily provide sensory feedback to the central nervous system.
What is the stretch reflex ?: The stretch reflex is an involuntary muscle contraction that occurs when a muscle is stretched. It is primarily mediated by muscle proprioceptors and helps maintain proper posture.
What is the pathway for the stretch refl: The stretch reflex pathway is a monosynaptic reflex arc that begins when a muscle spindle is stretched, causing an afferent sensory neuron to send information to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. This information then synapses with an alpha motor neuron in the anterior horn of the spinal cord, causing the muscle to contract.
What is the Golgi tendon organ ?: The Golgi tendon organ is a proprioceptor that senses changes in muscle tension. It is located at the junction between a muscle and its tendon.
What is the reverse stretch reflex ?: The reverse stretch reflex, also known as the inverse stretch reflex, is a reflex action mediated by the Golgi tendon organs. It causes a stretched muscle to relax when stimulated by a prolonged stretch. This reflex is the opposite of the myotatic reflex, which causes muscle contraction in response to stretching.
What are spinal interneurons ?: Spinal interneurons are neurons within the spinal cord that facilitate and modulate motor, sensory, and autonomic functions.
What is reciprocal inhibition ?: Reciprocal inhibition is a behavior therapy technique used to treat anxiety and phobias by gradually replacing anxiety-inducing responses with relaxation or neutralizing responses. It is based on the principle that conflicting emotions cannot be experienced simultaneously.
What is the flexor reflex ?: The flexor reflex is a spinal reflex that causes the flexor muscles of a limb to contract in response to a noxious or painful stimulus applied to the skin of that limb. This reflex helps protect the body by withdrawing the affected limb from harm.
What is the crossed extensor reflex ?: The crossed extensor reflex is a protective spinal reflex that causes one limb to withdraw from a painful stimulus while activating the extensor muscles of the opposite limb to maintain balance.
What are central pattern generators ?: Central pattern generators (CPGs) are neural circuits that produce rhythmic activity without relying on timing cues from sensory feedback or descending pathways. They underlie behaviors such as locomotion and breathing.
What is the highest level of the central: The highest level of the central motor system is the cerebellum.
What is the middle level of the central: The middle level of the central motor system includes structures such as the cerebellum, thalamus, basal nuclei, and brainstem. It specifies the postures and movements needed to carry out an intended action, taking into account sensory information about the body's position.
What is the lowest level of the central: The lowest level of the central motor system is the spinal cord.
What is the highest level of sensory fee: The highest level of sensory feedback to the motor control hierarchy is the sensory cortex, which is located in the frontal lobe of the brain. It is responsible for integrating sensory information with motor commands and planning complex movements.
What is the middle level of sensory feed: The middle level of sensory feedback to the motor hierarchy is the motor cortex. It receives input from afferent sensory receptors in muscles, tendons, joints, skin, and the vestibular apparatus. This information is integrated with input from higher levels of the motor hierarchy to specify individual postures and movements needed for an intended action.
What is the lowest level of sensory feed: The lowest level of sensory feedback to the motor hierarchy is proprioceptive input, which is received from the muscles and joints.
What are the descending spinal tracts ?: Descending spinal tracts are motor pathways that transmit signals from the brain to the spinal cord, coordinating movement. They include the corticospinal tract, rubrospinal tract, vestibulospinal tract, and reticulospinal tract.
What is the corticospinal tract ?: The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is a collection of axons that transmit movement-related information from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. It primarily controls voluntary movements of the limbs and trunk and consists of axons from upper motor neurons in the motor cortex.
What is the course for axons in the cort: The course for axons in the corticospinal pathway which originate in the cortex is through the corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract. These axons travel down through the brainstem, forming the corticospinal tract, and synapse on lower motor neurons and interneurons in the spinal cord's ventral horn.
What is another lateral descending pathw: Another lateral descending pathway is the rubrospinal tract, which originates in the red nucleus of the midbrain and descends through the pons and medulla oblongata to enter the lateral funiculus of the spinal cord.
What are the 4 ventromedial pathways ?: The 4 ventromedial pathways are the anterior corticospinal tract, the vestibulospinal tract, the reticulospinal tract, and the tectospinal tract.
What motor area innervates distal motor: The supplementary motor area (SMA) innervates distal motor units, while the premotor area (PMA) innervates proximal motor units.
What is apraxia ?: Apraxia is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability to perform purposeful movements and gestures despite having the desire and physical ability to do so. It can affect daily activities such as dressing, eating, and speaking.
What is the ready set go theory ?: The 'Ready, Set, Go' theory refers to a balanced approach to taking action, where individuals alternate between preparing and taking action. It emphasizes the importance of avoiding perfectionism and rushing into actions.
Where does the basal ganglia send info t: The basal ganglia send information to the cerebral cortex via the thalamus.
What is a major subcortical input to are: The major subcortical input to area 6 is from the basal ganglia.
Where does the basal ganglia receive inp: The basal ganglia receive inputs from various areas of the brain, including the cerebral cortex, thalamus, and hypothalamus.
What is the basal ganglia made up of ?: The basal ganglia are made up of several structures, including the striatum (which consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen), the globus pallidus, the subthalamic nucleus, and the substantia nigra.
What makes up the striatum ?: The striatum is primarily composed of spiny projection neurons (SPNs) and GABAergic and cholinergic interneurons. It includes the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, and substantia nigra.
What is the globus pallidus of the basal: The globus pallidus of the basal ganglia is important for controlling movement and coordination.
Which layer of m1 does the activation of: The activation of lower motor neurons originates in layer V of the primary motor cortex (M1). This layer contains large pyramidal neurons, known as Betz cells, which project to and excite the lower motor neurons.
What do the neurons of m1 encode ?: The neurons of M1 (primary motor cortex) encode the activity of muscle synergies rather than individual muscles or global movement parameters. They are broadly tuned to the direction of hand movement, with each neuron having a preferred direction.
What is ataxia ?: Ataxia is a loss of coordination and balance caused by neurological problems in the brain. It can cause symptoms such as slurred speech, stumbling, and unusual eye movements.
Why is dysnergia ?: Dyssynergic defecation, also known as pelvic floor dyssynergia, occurs when the muscles in the pelvic floor do not work together properly during bowel movements. This can lead to symptoms such as constipation and straining.
What is dysmetria ?: Dysmetria is a condition that affects one's ability to control and coordinate movements accurately. It is a type of ataxia, which is a group of disorders that affect coordination, balance, and movement. Dysmetria can manifest as difficulty with smooth, coordinated movements, such as walking or reaching for objects.
What is the cerebellum critical for?: The cerebellum is critical for motor control, coordination, and motor learning. It is involved in the planning and execution of complex movements, as well as maintaining posture and balance.
What are G proteins and how do they work: G proteins, or guanine nucleotide-binding proteins, are heterotrimeric proteins that bind guanosine triphosphate (GTP) and guanosine diphosphate (GDP) and work as molecular switches in cellular signaling. They are associated with G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) and play a crucial role in transmitting signals from external stimuli to the cell's interior. Upon activation by a receptor, G proteins undergo a conformational change, allowing them to interact with other intra
How do metabotropic receptors work ?: Metabotropic receptors, also known as G-protein-coupled receptors, work through signal transduction mechanisms involving G proteins. When a neurotransmitter binds to a metabotropic receptor, it triggers a series of intracellular events that can modulate cell activity. Unlike ionotropic receptors, metabotropic receptors do not have ion channels as part of their structure and instead rely on metabolic processes to regulate cell activity.
How many different GPCRs are there ?: There are over 800 different GPCRs in the human body.
What 2nd messenger system does norepinep: Norepinephrine uses the cyclic AMP (cAMP) second messenger system.
What 2nd messenger system does glutamate: Glutamate class 1 receptors, also known as metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs), use the G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) second messenger system.
Glutamate class 2 receptors, also known as metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs), use the cyclic AMP (cAMP) second messenger system.
What 2nd messenger system does dopamine: Dopamine uses the cAMP/adenylyl cyclase second messenger system through its D1 receptors, which are coupled to the Gs protein.
Where are mGluR1s mostly located and whe: mGluR1s are mostly located at the periphery of the subsynaptic region, while mGluR2+3s are more occasionally located at pre-terminal sites of presynaptic neurons and less abundantly on postsynaptic elements.
What is different about glutamate and GA: Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) and GABA metabotropic receptors (GABA B receptors) are both G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), but they differ from other GPCRs in their structural and functional properties. mGluRs and GABA B receptors are classified as atypical GPCRs, which means they have unique structural and functional characteristics compared to other GPCRs. Additionally, mGluRs and GABA B receptors have distinct signaling pathways and pharmacological effects compared to other GPCRs
What happens in long term depression in: Long-term depression (LTD) in the cerebellum is a persistent attenuation of the parallel fiber-Purkinje neuron synapse, resulting in reduced responsiveness to transmitter glutamate. This occurs through dephosphorylation of AMPA receptors and their movement away from the synaptic junction.
How do mGluR2s work at presynaptic neuro: mGluR2s work at presynaptic neurons by acting as autoreceptors for glutamate. Upon activation, mGluR2s inhibit the release of glutamate from the presynaptic terminal by coupling with the Gi alpha subunit and inhibiting the emptying of vesicular contents, thereby reducing glutamate release.
What are heteroreceptors?: Heteroreceptors are receptors that regulate the synthesis and/or release of mediators other than their own ligand.
What are GABAb receptors like ?: GABAB receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors that mediate the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. They are linked to potassium channels and their activation leads to hyperpolarization of the cell.
Why is acetylcholine in its own separate: Acetylcholine is in its own separate group as a neurotransmitter because it was the first neurotransmitter to be discovered and has unique functions in both the central and peripheral nervous systems.
Choline is an essential nutrient, where: Choline is an essential nutrient that we can get from a variety of foods. Some of the foods that are high in choline include: nuts, seeds, liver, eggs, and dairy products. However, it is important to note that the body also produces some choline, but not enough to meet daily needs.
What inhibits ChAT ?: ChAT, or choline acetyltransferase, is an enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of acetylcholine from choline. There are several compounds that can inhibit ChAT activity, including E1, E2, and E3.
How is acetylcholine stored ?: Acetylcholine is stored in vesicles at the ends of cholinergic neurons.
How is acetylcholine inactivated ?: Acetylcholine is inactivated by the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which converts it to choline and acetic acid. This process occurs in the synaptic cleft, the space between nerve and muscle, where acetylcholine interacts with its receptors.
What does sarin gas do ?: Sarin gas is a highly toxic and fast-acting nerve agent that disrupts the function of certain enzymes, causing muscle contractions and paralysis. Exposure to sarin can result in severe health effects such as seizures, paralysis, and difficulty breathing within minutes.
What does hemicolinium do to cholinergic: Hemicolinium inhibits cholinergic transmission by blocking the reuptake of choline by the high-affinity choline transporter, which is essential for acetylcholine synthesis. This leads to a decrease in acetylcholine levels at the presynapse and a decrease in cholinergic transmission.
What does vesamicol do to cholinergic tr: Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of acetylcholine into cholinergic neuronal storage vesicles, leading to a decrease in acetylcholine release. This decrease in acetylcholine release is responsible for the inhibition of cholinergic transmission.
What does botulinum do to cholinergic tr: Botulinum toxin inhibits cholinergic transmission by blocking the release of acetylcholine from cholinergic nerve terminals.
What does nicotine do to cholinergic tra: Nicotine stimulates cholinergic transmission by binding to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) and mimicking the effects of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter involved in various brain functions such as learning, memory, and reward.
What does scopolamine do to cholinergic: Scopolamine is a non-selective muscarinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist that blocks cholinergic transmission in the brain. It does this by competitively antagonizing the effects of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors. This disruption of cholinergic transmission can have a variety of effects, including effects on learning and memory.
What acts as an agonist at muscarinic ac: Pilocarpine is a drug that acts as an agonist at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.
Where is acetylcholine present in the PN: Acetylcholine is present in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) as a neurotransmitter in preganglionic sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons, as well as at the neuromuscular junction.
Where is acetylcholine present in the CN: Acetylcholine is present in the central nervous system (CNS) at various sites, including synapses, neurons, and glial cells.
How are cholinergic neurons identified ?: Cholinergic neurons are identified by the presence of the enzyme choline acetyltransferase (ChAT), which synthesizes the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. This enzyme can be detected through immunohistochemical staining, which uses antibodies to detect the protein.
Where are the major cholinergic clusters: The major cholinergic clusters in the CNS are located in the hippocampal complex, olfactory bulb, cerebral cortex, and amygdala.
Where are alpha-3 beta-4 acetylcholine r: Alpha-3 beta-4 acetylcholine receptors are found in various parts of the brain and nervous system, including the autonomic ganglia, adrenal medulla, brainstem, spinal cord, and hippocampal region.
Where are alpha-7 acetylcholine receptor: Alpha-7 acetylcholine receptors are present in various immune cells such as macrophages, dendritic cells, T and B lymphocytes, mast cells, and basophils. They are also present in various neuronal and non-neuronal tissues.
Where are alpha-4 beta-2 acetylcholine r: Alpha-4 beta-2 acetylcholine receptors are primarily present in the brain and spinal cord. They are the most abundant class of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system.
Where are m1 acetylcholine receptors pre: M1 acetylcholine receptors are primarily present in the central nervous system (CNS) and exocrine glands.
Where are m2 acetylcholine receptor?: The M2 acetylcholine receptor is primarily found in the parasympathetic nervous system and is involved in various physiological processes.
Where are m3 acetylcholine receptors exp: M3 acetylcholine receptors are expressed in a wide range of tissues and organs, including smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, exocrine glands, and neurons in the central and peripheral nervous systems.
Where are m4a acetylcholine receptors ex: M4a acetylcholine receptors are expressed in various regions of the brain, including the cortex, hippocampus, and striatum. They are also expressed in the epidermis, specifically in keratinocytes and melanocytes.
In knocked out mice where are the m1 rec: In knocked out mice, M1 receptors are predominantly expressed in the hippocampus and frontal cortex. Their function is to play a crucial role in memory formation and synaptic plasticity. Inhibition or ablation of M1 receptors disrupts the encoding and retrieval of spatial memories.
In knocked out mice where are the m2rece: M2 receptors are primarily expressed in peripheral tissues such as the heart and colon, as well as in a subset of glutamatergic synapses and GABAergic interneurons in the brain. Their function includes regulating heart rate and acting as presynaptic autoreceptors, which modulate neurotransmitter release.
In knocked out mice where are the m3 rec: In knocked out mice, M3 receptors are expressed in the hippocampus and amygdala. Their function is related to mediating fear conditioning responses in the hippocampus and may play a role in dopamine release in the striatum.
In knocked out mice where are the m4 rec: In knocked out mice, M4 receptors are expressed in various tissues, including the brain, heart, and peripheral nerves. Their function involves modulating neurotransmitter release and regulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.
In knocked out mice where are the m5 rec: M5 receptors are primarily expressed in the midbrain dopaminergic neurons, specifically in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra. Their function involves modulation of central dopamine signaling and the tone of cerebral blood vessels.
How is GABA synthesised ?: GABA is synthesised from the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate by the enzyme glutamate decarboxylase (GAD), which catalyzes the decarboxylation of glutamic acid to form GABA.
What are examples of inhibitory amino ac: Examples of inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitters include gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine.
How is GABA broken down ?: GABA is broken down by the enzyme GABA transaminase to form succinic semialdehyde, which is then converted into succinic acid.
What inhibits GABA-T ?: GABA-T (GABA transaminase) is inhibited by various compounds such as vigabatrin, lisdexamfetamine, and risperidone. These compounds can be used to treat conditions such as Huntington's disease, epilepsy, and multiple sclerosis.
What happens to the succinic semialdehyd: Succinic semialdehyde is oxidized to succinic acid by the enzyme succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase, which uses NAD+ as a cofactor. This process shunts succinic acid into the TCA (tricarboxylic acid) cycle for further metabolism.
What is vigabatrin used to treat ?: Vigabatrin is used to treat refractory complex partial seizures and infantile spasms. It may also be used off-label for conditions such as migraines and neuropathic pain.
What 2 substances can make GABA ?: Two substances that can make GABA are glutamic acid and -ketoglutarate.
What are the GABA receptors ?: GABA receptors are a class of ion channels that respond to the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). There are two main classes of GABA receptors: GABAA and GABAB. GABAA receptors are ligand-gated ion channels that allow the flow of chloride ions, while GABAB receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that mediate slower inhibitory effects.
What effect does GABA binding to GABAa r: GABA binding to GABAa receptors in adult cells mediates both phasic and tonic neuronal inhibition in the central nervous system. This effect is achieved by allowing the passage of chloride ions into the cell, which inhibits the activity of signal-receiving neurons.
What are the subunits of a GABA receptor: The subunits of a GABA receptor are heteropentameric, consisting of two alpha ( 1-6), two beta ( 1-3), and one gamma ( 1-3) or delta ( 1-3) subunits. Each subunit has a large extracellular N-terminus, four transmembrane -helices, and a barely structured intracellular loop.
What is the subunit diversity like in GA: GABAa receptors exhibit significant subunit diversity. The majority of GABAa receptors are composed of two  subunits, two  subunits, and one  subunit. However, there are several isoforms and subtypes of GABAa receptors that exhibit different pharmacological properties.
What loop binds GABA and what domain mak: GABA binds to the extracellular domain (ECD) of GABA A receptors. The pore is formed by the second helix, M2, of the transmembrane domain (TMD).
What are the 5 distinct binding sites on: The five distinct binding sites on a GABAa receptor are for GABA, benzodiazepines, barbiturates, picrotoxin, and anesthetic steroids.
What happens when benzodiazepines bind t: When benzodiazepines bind to GABAa receptors, they enhance GABA-induced chloride ion flux, leading to neuronal hyperpolarization. This results in increased inhibitory postsynaptic potential, facilitating the inhibitory actions of GABA.
What happens when picrotoxin binds to GA: When picrotoxin binds to GABAa receptors, it acts as a competitive antagonist, interfering with the receptor's ability to mediate inhibitory neurotransmission. This can lead to increased neuronal excitability and convulsions.
What effects occur when GABAb is stimula: When GABAb is stimulated, it results in prolonged inhibition of neurotransmission. This effect is crucial for maintaining proper neurotransmitter balance in the brain.
What are agonists at GABAb receptors ?: Agonists at GABAb receptors are drugs that activate these receptors, producing effects such as sedation, anxiolysis, and muscle relaxation. Baclofen (Lioresal) is the only FDA-approved drug that selectively targets GABAb receptors and is used to treat conditions such as muscle spasms, alcohol dependency, and cataplexy.
What are antagonists for GABAb receptors: There are several antagonists for GABAb receptors, including saclofen, 4,5,6,7-tetrahydroisoxazolo[5,4-c]pyridin-3-ol (THIP), and various phosphonic and sulfonic acid analogues of baclofen.
Where are glycine receptors located ?: Glycine receptors are primarily located in the spinal cord and various regions of the brain.
How is glycine synthesised ?: Glycine is synthesized from serine by the mitochondrial isoform of serine hydroxymethyltransferase. It can also be synthesized from threonine, choline, and hydroxyproline through inter-organ metabolism involving primarily the liver and kidneys.
How is glycine taken up from the synapti: Glycine is taken up from the synaptic cleft by high-affinity uptake systems, such as the GlyT-1 transporter. These transporters can switch between normal and reverse modes depending on the concentration of glycine in the synaptic cleft.
How is glycine packaged into vesicles ?: Glycine is packaged into vesicles by the vesicular inhibitory amino acid transporter (VIAAT) in the presynaptic terminal.
From rat spinal cord what is the structu: The structure of glycine receptors from rat spinal cord is a pentameric anion channel composed of four  subunits and one  subunit.
What is the structure of the glycine rec: The glycine receptor is a pentameric anion channel composed of five subunits, two 1 subunits and three  subunits. It is similar to the GABA A receptor in that it is a cys-loop ligand-gated channel. The glycine receptor can be homomeric (all  subunits) or heteromeric (a mix of  and  subunits).
What is the purpose of gephyrin in the g: Gephyrin in the glycine receptor plays a crucial role in the stabilization and clustering of glycine receptors at inhibitory synapses. It forms a hexagonal lattice that serves as a scaffold for these receptors and other accessory proteins.
What is the glycine receptor involved in: The glycine receptor is involved in inhibitory neurotransmission in the central nervous system. It is a ligand-gated chloride channel that allows for an influx of chloride ions into the cytoplasm, hyperpolarizing the postsynaptic membrane.
What happens in hyperperplexia ?: Hyperperplexia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by an exaggerated startle reflex in response to sudden noises, movements, or touch. It is caused by mutations in specific genes that affect the nervous system's response to glycine, leading to symptoms such as muscle stiffness and spasms.
What is hyperperplexia treated with ?: Hyperperplexia is typically treated with clonazepam, an anti-anxiety and antispastic medication.
What increases glycine release ?: Glycine release can be increased by a variety of factors, including temperature, glycine concentration, and activation of the glycine transporter (GlyT-1).
